20101203140027.079|20101203140028.849|TR0|
20101203140028.849|20101203140030.619|TR0|More revelations continue to 
20101203140030.619|20101203140032.389|TR0|emerge from the U.S. State 
20101203140032.389|20101203140034.159|TR0|Department cables released by 
20101203140034.159|20101203140035.929|TR0|the online whistleblower group 
20101203140035.929|20101203140037.699|TR0|WikiLeaks. The latest cables to 
20101203140037.699|20101203140039.469|TR0|be disclosed show the CIA 
20101203140039.469|20101203140041.239|TR0|spearheaded the State 
20101203140041.239|20101203140043.009|TR0|Department's program to spy on 
20101203140043.009|20101203140044.779|TR0|foreign diplomats. Although the 
20101203140044.779|20101203140046.549|TR0|orders were authorized by U.S. 
20101203140046.549|20101203140048.319|TR0|Secretary of States Condoleezza 
20101203140048.319|20101203140050.089|TR0|Rice and her successor, Hillary 
20101203140050.089|20101203140051.859|TR0|Clinton, The Guardian of London 
20101203140051.859|20101203140053.629|TR0|reports a CIA official drew up 
20101203140053.629|20101203140055.399|TR0|the instructions for who should 
20101203140055.399|20101203140057.169|TR0|be monitored and what 
20101203140057.169|20101203140058.939|TR0|information should be tracked. 
20101203140058.939|20101203140100.709|TR0|The targets of the U.S. spying 
20101203140100.709|20101203140102.479|TR0|included U.N. Secretary-General 
20101203140102.479|20101203140104.249|TR0|Ban Ki-moon and other top U.N. 
20101203140104.249|20101203140106.019|TR0|officials.

20101203140111.328|20101203140113.098|TR0|Cables: Britain Allowed U.S. 
20101203140113.098|20101203140114.868|TR0|Cluster Bombs
20101203140114.868|20101203140116.638|TR0|
20101203140116.638|20101203140118.408|TR0|The WikiLeaks released embassy 
20101203140118.408|20101203140120.178|TR0|cables also show Britain has 
20101203140120.178|20101203140121.948|TR0|allowed the United States to 
20101203140121.948|20101203140123.718|TR0|store banned cluster bombs on 
20101203140123.718|20101203140125.488|TR0|British soil. Britain signed the 
20101203140125.488|20101203140127.258|TR0|international convention barring 
20101203140127.258|20101203140129.028|TR0|cluster munitions in December 
20101203140129.028|20101203140130.798|TR0|2008. But six months later, a 
20101203140130.798|20101203140132.568|TR0|U.S. embassy cable said Britain 
20101203140132.568|20101203140134.338|TR0|had agreed to keep silent about 
20101203140134.338|20101203140136.108|TR0|a dealing allowing the United 
20101203140136.108|20101203140137.878|TR0|States to store cluster bombs 
20101203140137.878|20101203140139.648|TR0|until 2013.

20101203140148.498|20101203140150.268|TR0|Civilians
20101203140150.268|20101203140152.038|TR0|
20101203140152.038|20101203140153.808|TR0|According to Amnesty 
20101203140153.808|20101203140155.578|TR0|International, the leaked 
20101203140155.578|20101203140157.348|TR0|embassy cables also confirm 
20101203140157.348|20101203140159.117|TR0|reports of massive civilian 
20101203140159.117|20101203140200.887|TR0|casualties in a U.S. attack on 
20101203140200.887|20101203140202.657|TR0|Yemen one year ago. The cables 
20101203140202.657|20101203140204.427|TR0|disclosed that the Yemeni 
20101203140204.427|20101203140206.197|TR0|government agreed to falsely 
20101203140206.197|20101203140207.967|TR0|claim they were carrying out 
20101203140207.967|20101203140209.737|TR0|missile strikes that were 
20101203140209.737|20101203140211.507|TR0|actually coming from the U.S. 
20101203140211.507|20101203140213.277|TR0|military. Yemen's Deputy Prime 
20101203140213.277|20101203140215.047|TR0|Minister is quoted mentioning 
20101203140215.047|20101203140216.817|TR0|the Abyan strike, in which 
20101203140216.817|20101203140218.587|TR0|dozens of local residents were 
20101203140218.587|20101203140220.357|TR0|killed, including 21 children. 
20101203140220.357|20101203140222.127|TR0|In June, Amnesty released 
20101203140222.127|20101203140223.897|TR0|photographs showing the remnants

20101203140225.667|20101203140227.437|TR0|site of the attack.

20101203140250.446|20101203140252.216|TR0|cable from January says Sri

20101203140338.235|20101203140340.005|TR0|imposed an order barring

20101203140341.775|20101203140343.545|TR0|leaked WikiLeaks cables. State

20101203140345.315|20101203140347.085|TR0|told not to read cables because 
20101203140347.085|20101203140348.855|TR0|they were classified and subject

20101203140633.462|20101203140635.232|TR0|Law Enforcement Agencies Conduct 
20101203140635.232|20101203140637.002|TR0|"Real-Time" Spying Without Court 
20101203140637.002|20101203140638.772|TR0|Orders
20101203140638.772|20101203140640.542|TR0|
20101203140640.542|20101203140642.312|TR0|Newly released documents show 
20101203140642.312|20101203140644.082|TR0|warrantless government spying is 
20101203140644.082|20101203140645.852|TR0|continuing with real-time 
20101203140645.852|20101203140647.622|TR0|tracking of Americans' everyday 
20101203140647.622|20101203140649.392|TR0|transactions. A government memo 
20101203140649.392|20101203140651.162|TR0|obtained by privacy activist 
20101203140651.162|20101203140652.932|TR0|Christopher Soghoian shows law 
20101203140652.932|20101203140654.701|TR0|enforcement agencies have been 
20101203140654.701|20101203140656.471|TR0|able to monitor targets by 
20101203140656.471|20101203140658.241|TR0|obtaining their credit cards, 
20101203140658.241|20101203140700.011|TR0|loyalty cards and travel 
20101203140700.011|20101203140701.781|TR0|bookings without a court order. 
20101203140701.781|20101203140703.551|TR0|Agents can obtain the so-called 
20101203140703.551|20101203140705.321|TR0|"Hotwatch" orders by writing up 
20101203140705.321|20101203140707.091|TR0|their own subpoena and getting a 
20101203140707.091|20101203140708.861|TR0|judge to rule that it cannot be 
20101203140708.861|20101203140710.631|TR0|disclosed. The American Civil 
20101203140710.631|20101203140712.401|TR0|Liberties Union has released 
20101203140712.401|20101203140714.171|TR0|hundreds of pages of government 
20101203140714.171|20101203140715.941|TR0|documents it says show the 
20101203140715.941|20101203140717.711|TR0|government continues to violate 
20101203140717.711|20101203140719.481|TR0|legal limits on domestic 
20101203140719.481|20101203140721.251|TR0|surveillance. The documents 
20101203140721.251|20101203140723.021|TR0|acknowledge breaches in 
20101203140723.021|20101203140724.791|TR0|collecting personal information 
20101203140724.791|20101203140726.561|TR0|but do not specify how many 
20101203140726.561|20101203140728.331|TR0|people have been affected.
20101203140728.331|20101203140730.101|TR0|
20101203140730.101|20101203140731.871|SEG|Type=Headline
20101203140731.871|20101203140733.641|TR0|
20101203140733.641|20101203140735.411|TR0|McCain Opposes Repeal of "Don't 
20101203140735.411|20101203140737.181|TR0|Ask, Don't Tell"
20101203140737.181|20101203140738.951|TR0|
20101203140738.951|20101203140740.721|TR0|Republican Senator John McCain 
20101203140740.721|20101203140742.491|TR0|of Arizona has given new 
20101203140742.491|20101203140744.260|TR0|indications he plans to block a 
20101203140744.260|20101203140746.030|TR0|repeal of the military's ban on 
20101203140746.030|20101203140747.800|TR0|gay and lesbian servicemembers 
20101203140747.800|20101203140749.570|TR0|known as the "Don't Ask, Don't 
20101203140749.570|20101203140751.340|TR0|Tell" policy. On Thursday, 
20101203140751.340|20101203140753.110|TR0|McCain told a Senate hearing 
20101203140753.110|20101203140754.880|TR0|that he doubted this week's 
20101203140754.880|20101203140756.650|TR0|Pentagon study that a repeal 
20101203140756.650|20101203140758.420|TR0|would have little impact.
20101203140758.420|20101203140800.190|TR0|
20101203140800.190|20101203140801.960|TR0|Sen. John McCain: "This is a 
20101203140801.960|20101203140803.730|TR0|complex and important issue that 
20101203140803.730|20101203140805.500|TR0|could have significant 
20101203140805.500|20101203140807.270|TR0|repercussions for our force, a 
20101203140807.270|20101203140809.040|TR0|force that is engaged in its 
20101203140809.040|20101203140810.810|TR0|tenth straight year of sustained 
20101203140810.810|20101203140812.580|TR0|combat, but a force that is 
20101203140812.580|20101203140814.350|TR0|performing exceptionally well. 
20101203140814.350|20101203140816.120|TR0|At this time, we should be 
20101203140816.120|20101203140817.890|TR0|inherently cautious about making 
20101203140817.890|20101203140819.660|TR0|any changes that would affect 
20101203140819.660|20101203140821.430|TR0|our military, and what changes 
20101203140821.430|20101203140823.200|TR0|we do make should be the product 
20101203140823.200|20101203140824.970|TR0|of careful and deliberate 
20101203140824.970|20101203140826.740|TR0|consideration. I'm not saying 
20101203140826.740|20101203140828.510|TR0|that this law should never 
20101203140828.510|20101203140830.280|TR0|change. I am simply saying that 
20101203140830.280|20101203140832.049|TR0|it may be premature to make such 
20101203140832.049|20101203140833.819|TR0|a change at this time and in 
20101203140833.819|20101203140835.589|TR0|this manner."
20101203140835.589|20101203140837.359|TR0|
20101203140837.359|20101203140839.129|TR0|Democrats have called for a 
20101203140839.129|20101203140840.899|TR0|repeal vote before the end of 
20101203140840.899|20101203140842.669|TR0|the year. The chair of the Joint 
20101203140842.669|20101203140844.439|TR0|Chiefs of Staff, Admiral Mike 
20101203140844.439|20101203140846.209|TR0|Mullen, said the military is 
20101203140846.209|20101203140847.979|TR0|ready for a repeal.
20101203140847.979|20101203140849.749|TR0|
20101203140849.749|20101203140851.519|TR0|Adm. Mike Mullen: "I'm convinced 
20101203140851.519|20101203140853.289|TR0|that repeal of the law governing 
20101203140853.289|20101203140855.059|TR0|'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' is the 
20101203140855.059|20101203140856.829|TR0|right thing to do. Back in 
20101203140856.829|20101203140858.599|TR0|February when I testified to 
20101203140858.599|20101203140900.369|TR0|this sentiment, I also said that

20101203140902.139|20101203140903.909|TR0|the Armed Forces could

20101203141703.569|20101203141705.339|TR0|We welcome you both to Democracy 
20101203141705.339|20101203141707.109|TR0|Now! Why don't we begin with 
20101203141707.109|20101203141708.879|TR0|Steven Aftergood? You have been 
20101203141708.879|20101203141710.649|TR0|a fierce proponent of 
20101203141710.649|20101203141712.419|TR0|transparency, yet you are a 
20101203141712.419|20101203141714.189|TR0|critic of WikiLeaks. Why?
20101203141714.189|20101203141715.959|TR0|
20101203141715.959|20101203141717.729|TR0|>> STEVEN AFTERGOOD: I'm all for 
20101203141717.729|20101203141719.499|TR0|the exposure of corruption, 
20101203141719.499|20101203141721.269|TR0|including classified corruption. 
20101203141721.269|20101203141723.039|TR0|And to the extent that WikiLeaks 
20101203141723.039|20101203141724.809|TR0|has done that, I support its 
20101203141724.809|20101203141726.579|TR0|actions. The problem is, it has 
20101203141726.579|20101203141728.349|TR0|done a lot more than that, much 
20101203141728.349|20101203141730.119|TR0|of which is problematic. It has 
20101203141730.119|20101203141731.889|TR0|invaded personal privacy. It has 
20101203141731.889|20101203141733.658|TR0|published libelous material. It 
20101203141733.658|20101203141735.428|TR0|has violated intellectual 
20101203141735.428|20101203141737.198|TR0|property rights. And above all, 
20101203141737.198|20101203141738.968|TR0|it has launched a sweeping 
20101203141738.968|20101203141740.738|TR0|attack not simply on corruption, 
20101203141740.738|20101203141742.508|TR0|but on secrecy itself. And I 
20101203141742.508|20101203141744.278|TR0|think that's both a strategic 
20101203141744.278|20101203141746.048|TR0|and a tactical error. It's a 
20101203141746.048|20101203141747.818|TR0|strategic error because some 
20101203141747.818|20101203141749.588|TR0|secrecy is perfectly legitimate 
20101203141749.588|20101203141751.358|TR0|and desirable. It's a tactical 
20101203141751.358|20101203141753.128|TR0|error because it has unleashed a 
20101203141753.128|20101203141754.898|TR0|furious response from the U.S. 
20101203141754.898|20101203141756.668|TR0|government and other governments

20101203142522.699|20101203142524.469|TR0|are, and it's then our 
20101203142524.469|20101203142526.239|TR0|responsibility to go about and 
20101203142526.239|20101203142528.009|TR0|do something about them.
20101203142528.009|20101203142529.779|TR0|
20101203142529.779|20101203142531.549|TR0|Again, they're a four-year-old 
20101203142531.549|20101203142533.319|TR0|organization. And they have led 
20101203142533.319|20101203142535.089|TR0|to all sorts of important 
20101203142535.089|20101203142536.859|TR0|reforms. I mean, in Iceland, 
20101203142536.859|20101203142538.629|TR0|WikiLeaks was basically the 
20101203142538.629|20101203142540.399|TR0|single-handed cause of a new law 
20101203142540.399|20101203142542.169|TR0|that is designed to protect 
20101203142542.169|20101203142543.939|TR0|whistleblowing and 
20101203142543.939|20101203142545.708|TR0|whistleblowing sites like 
20101203142545.708|20101203142547.478|TR0|WikiLeaks beyond anything else 
20101203142547.478|20101203142549.248|TR0|that exists in the world. Their 
20101203142549.248|20101203142551.018|TR0|exposure of corruption on the 
20101203142551.018|20101203142552.788|TR0|part of a Iceland's biggest 
20101203142552.788|20101203142554.558|TR0|banks, that led to the financial 
20101203142554.558|20101203142556.328|TR0|meltdown, led to investigations 
20101203142556.328|20101203142558.098|TR0|and prosecutions. The same thing 
20101203142558.098|20101203142559.868|TR0|happened to exposure of 
20101203142559.868|20101203142601.638|TR0|injustices and corruption on the 
20101203142601.638|20101203142603.408|TR0|part of oil magnates in Peru. 
20101203142603.408|20101203142605.178|TR0|They exposed the Australian 
20101203142605.178|20101203142606.948|TR0|government's efforts to target 
20101203142606.948|20101203142608.718|TR0|websites to be shut down under a 
20101203142608.718|20101203142610.488|TR0|program designed to target child 
20101203142610.488|20101203142612.258|TR0|pornography, when in reality the 
20101203142612.258|20101203142614.028|TR0|sites that were targeted were 
20101203142614.028|20101203142615.798|TR0|political sites. And in Spain 
20101203142615.798|20101203142617.568|TR0|this week, the headlines are 
20101203142617.568|20101203142619.338|TR0|dominated by documents that 
20101203142619.338|20101203142621.108|TR0|WikiLeaks released that you,

20101203142637.037|20101203142638.807|TR0|And so you see all over the

20101203142715.977|20101203142717.747|TR0|of view, WikiLeaks is poorly 
20101203142717.747|20101203142719.517|TR0|focused in order to achieve its 
20101203142719.517|20101203142721.287|TR0|objective. And let me say, of 
20101203142721.287|20101203142723.056|TR0|course, I supported the release 
20101203142723.056|20101203142724.826|TR0|of the Apache helicopter video. 
20101203142724.826|20101203142726.596|TR0|I started out by saying that I 
20101203142726.596|20101203142728.366|TR0|favor the unauthorized 
20101203142728.366|20101203142730.136|TR0|disclosure of classified 
20101203142730.136|20101203142731.906|TR0|information that reveals 
20101203142731.906|20101203142733.676|TR0|corruption. It's very hard, 
20101203142733.676|20101203142735.446|TR0|evidently, to say both good and 
20101203142735.446|20101203142737.216|TR0|bad things about WikiLeaks. 
20101203142737.216|20101203142738.986|TR0|People want you to say only one 
20101203142738.986|20101203142740.756|TR0|or the other.
20101203142740.756|20101203142742.526|TR0|
20101203142742.526|20101203142744.296|TR0|But yesterday, Der Spiegel 
20101203142744.296|20101203142746.066|TR0|reported that a member, an 
20101203142746.066|20101203142747.836|TR0|official from the Free 
20101203142747.836|20101203142749.606|TR0|Democratic Party, had been

20101203142801.996|20101203142803.766|TR0|victory for open government, but

20101203142807.306|20101203142809.076|TR0|or hundreds of thousands of 
20101203142809.076|20101203142810.846|TR0|times over, it does real damage

20101203142830.315|20101203142832.085|TR0|have a cavalier or 
20101203142832.085|20101203142833.855|TR0|indiscriminate approach to 
20101203142833.855|20101203142835.625|TR0|disclosure, contrary to 
20101203142835.625|20101203142837.395|TR0|accusations often made against 
20101203142837.395|20101203142839.165|TR0|it. They've certainly made 
20101203142839.165|20101203142840.935|TR0|mistakes in the past. I 
20101203142840.935|20101203142842.705|TR0|criticize them, for instance, 
20101203142842.705|20101203142844.475|TR0|for exercising insufficient care

20101203143340.059|20101203143341.829|TR0|first, here on Democracy Now!, 
20101203143341.829|20101203143343.599|TR0|we've conducted three extensive

20101203143352.449|20101203143354.219|TR0|told us in 
20101203143354.219|20101203143355.988|TR0|transparentgovernment">July on 
20101203143355.988|20101203143357.758|TR0|government transparency.
20101203143357.758|20101203143359.528|TR0|
20101203143359.528|20101203143401.298|TR0|>> JULIAN ASSANGE: We have 
20101203143401.298|20101203143403.068|TR0|clearly stated motives, but they 
20101203143403.068|20101203143404.838|TR0|are not antiwar motives. We are 
20101203143404.838|20101203143406.608|TR0|not pacifists. We are 
20101203143406.608|20101203143408.378|TR0|transparency activists who 
20101203143408.378|20101203143410.148|TR0|understand that transparent 
20101203143410.148|20101203143411.918|TR0|government tends to produce just 
20101203143411.918|20101203143413.688|TR0|government. And that is our sort

20101203143526.257|20101203143528.027|TR0|the first time, the United 
20101203143528.027|20101203143529.797|TR0|States declassified and 
20101203143529.797|20101203143531.567|TR0|disclosed the size of its 
20101203143531.567|20101203143533.337|TR0|nuclear weapons arsenal. This

20101203144146.799|20101203144148.569|TR0|cables on the New York Times or 
20101203144148.569|20101203144150.339|TR0|other sites. It's obviously 
20101203144150.339|20101203144152.109|TR0|ridiculous. You know, this whole 
20101203144152.109|20101203144153.879|TR0|"cablegate" was intended as a 
20101203144153.879|20101203144155.649|TR0|provocation. Bradley Manning 
20101203144155.649|20101203144157.419|TR0|said it would give thousands of 
20101203144157.419|20101203144159.189|TR0|diplomats heart attacks. The 
20101203144159.189|20101203144200.959|TR0|system has been provoked. It is 
20101203144200.959|20101203144202.729|TR0|- you know, it is outrageous. 
20101203144202.729|20101203144204.499|TR0|It's kind of disgusting. The 
20101203144204.499|20101203144206.269|TR0|question is, is it good 
20101203144206.269|20101203144208.038|TR0|politics? I don't think so.
20101203144208.038|20101203144209.808|TR0|
20101203144209.808|20101203144211.578|TR0|>> AMY GOODMAN: Finally, Glenn 
20101203144211.578|20101203144213.348|TR0|Greenwald, your final response?

20101203144215.118|20101203144216.888|TR0|>> GLENN GREENWALD: I think that 
20101203144216.888|20101203144218.658|TR0|that response is not one caused

20101203144220.428|20101203144222.198|TR0|response is reflective of what

20101203144223.968|20101203144225.738|TR0|that prevails. And it's every

20101203144512.115|20101203144513.885|TR0|all, I'm going to back up and 
20101203144513.885|20101203144515.655|TR0|talk about why this matters. 
20101203144515.655|20101203144517.425|TR0|What most people don't 
20101203144517.425|20101203144519.195|TR0|understand when they hear "net 
20101203144519.195|20101203144520.965|TR0|neutrality," their eyes gloss 
20101203144520.965|20101203144522.735|TR0|over, and they say, "How does 
20101203144522.735|20101203144524.504|TR0|that affect me?" What's going on 
20101203144524.504|20101203144526.274|TR0|right now is we're in the middle 
20101203144526.274|20101203144528.044|TR0|of a major transition from one 
20101203144528.044|20101203144529.814|TR0|media technology to another 
20101203144529.814|20101203144531.584|TR0|media technology: the internet, 
20101203144531.584|20101203144533.354|TR0|the first two-way experience. 
20101203144533.354|20101203144535.124|TR0|And with the internet brings 
20101203144535.124|20101203144536.894|TR0|this possibility that any 
20101203144536.894|20101203144538.664|TR0|website could act as a 
20101203144538.664|20101203144540.434|TR0|television network, a radio 
20101203144540.434|20101203144542.204|TR0|network. It is the ultimate game 
20101203144542.204|20101203144543.974|TR0|changer in the future of how 
20101203144543.974|20101203144545.744|TR0|Americans access information and 
20101203144545.744|20101203144547.514|TR0|learn about the world. Now, what 
20101203144547.514|20101203144549.284|TR0|we're seeing is, since the 
20101203144549.284|20101203144551.054|TR0|internet started about 40 years 
20101203144551.054|20101203144552.824|TR0|ago, there's this principle 
20101203144552.824|20101203144554.594|TR0|called "net neutrality." And it 
20101203144554.594|20101203144556.364|TR0|essentially says that the 
20101203144556.364|20101203144558.134|TR0|companies that bring you the 
20101203144558.134|20101203144559.904|TR0|internet into your home or 
20101203144559.904|20101203144601.674|TR0|business cannot indiscriminately 
20101203144601.674|20101203144603.444|TR0|say, "This is going to move 
20101203144603.444|20101203144605.214|TR0|fast, this is going to move 
20101203144605.214|20101203144606.984|TR0|slow, and that's our decision," 
20101203144606.984|20101203144608.754|TR0|in order to make more money or 
20101203144608.754|20101203144610.524|TR0|for political gain or what have 
20101203144610.524|20101203144612.294|TR0|you. So what we're seeing is, as 
20101203144612.294|20101203144614.063|TR0|the internet becomes more 
20101203144614.063|20101203144615.833|TR0|ubiquitous, the companies that 
20101203144615.833|20101203144617.603|TR0|deliver the internet - Comcast, 
20101203144617.603|20101203144619.373|TR0|AT&T, Verizon - they enjoy 
20101203144619.373|20101203144621.143|TR0|monopoly or duopoly control of 
20101203144621.143|20101203144622.913|TR0|connections, and they want to 
20101203144622.913|20101203144624.683|TR0|monetize the internet by getting 
20101203144624.683|20101203144626.453|TR0|rid of rules that prevent them 
20101203144626.453|20101203144628.223|TR0|from creating fast lanes and 
20101203144628.223|20101203144629.993|TR0|slow lanes.

20101203145025.398|20101203145027.168|TR0|now in Sweden - I think it's 
20101203145027.168|20101203145028.938|TR0|called Bahnhof - which is 
20101203145028.938|20101203145030.708|TR0|providing that kind of access to 
20101203145030.708|20101203145032.478|TR0|the internet to WikiLeaks. We've 
20101203145032.478|20101203145034.248|TR0|got to stop them from doing 
20101203145034.248|20101203145036.018|TR0|that, and we've got to apprehend 
20101203145036.018|20101203145037.788|TR0|Mr. Assange, the founder of

20101203145048.408|20101203145050.178|TR0|Lieberman. Amazon.com dropped

20101203145100.798|20101203145102.568|TR0|becomes a policy question, when 
20101203145102.568|20101203145104.338|TR0|I look at it. And the question

20101203145132.657|20101203145134.427|TR0|neutrality is part of a larger

20101203145136.197|20101203145137.967|TR0|not caught up with the
